natural problem: Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: Given any pair of the 4 CDs, there is exactly one arrangement with only these two CDs in the correct cases, because each of the remaining two CDs must be in the case of the other one.

Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> n. if n = 2 then 1 / 4 else 0)"
shows  "probability 2 = 1 / 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Given any pair of the 4 CDs, there is exactly one arrangement with only these two CDs in the correct cases, because each of the remaining two CDs must be in the case of the other one.
 Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> n. if n = 2 then 1 / 4 else 0)"
shows  "probability 2 = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A probability function is defined as follows: $P(n) = \frac{1}{4}$ if $n = 2$, and $P(n) = 0$ otherwise. What is the probability of $n = 2$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_1.formal problem:

fixes num_cds :: real
assumes h0 : "num_cds = 4"
shows  "probability_exactly_two_in_wrong_cases = 1 / 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_cds :: real
assumes h0 : "num_cds = 4"
shows  "probability_exactly_two_in_wrong_cases = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a collection of 4 CDs, find the probability that exactly two of them are in the wrong cases. The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = 1 / 4"
shows  "P = (card {p :: (int * int) set. bij p \<and> card {i. i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> p i \<noteq> i} = 2}) / fact 4"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Given any pair of the 4 CDs, there is exactly one arrangement with only these two CDs in the correct cases, because each of the remaining two CDs must be in the case of the other one.
 Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = 1 / 4"
shows  "P = (card {p :: (int * int) set. bij p \<and> card {i. i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> p i \<noteq> i} = 2}) / fact 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the probability that a permutation of the set {1, 2, 3, 4} has exactly two elements not in their original position. The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> n m. fact n / (fact m * fact (n - m))) 4 2 / fact 4"
shows  "probability = 1 / 4"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Given any pair of the 4 CDs, there is exactly one arrangement with only these two CDs in the correct cases, because each of the remaining two CDs must be in the case of the other one.
 Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> n m. fact n / (fact m * fact (n - m))) 4 2 / fact 4"
shows  "probability = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the probability of choosing 2 items from a set of 4 items. The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> x. if x = 2 then 1/4 else 0)"
shows  "probability 2 = 1/4"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Given any pair of the 4 CDs, there is exactly one arrangement with only these two CDs in the correct cases, because each of the remaining two CDs must be in the case of the other one.
 Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> x. if x = 2 then 1/4 else 0)"
shows  "probability 2 = 1/4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a probability function $P(x)$ such that $P(x) = \frac{1}{4}$ if $x = 2$ and $0$ otherwise, find the probability of $x = 2$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat" and N :: nat
assumes h0 : "N = 4"
and h1 : "probability = (\<lambda>n. fact N / fact (N - n) / (fact n * fact N))"
shows  "probability 2 = 1 / 4"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Given any pair of the 4 CDs, there is exactly one arrangement with only these two CDs in the correct cases, because each of the remaining two CDs must be in the case of the other one.
 Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat" and N :: nat
assumes h0 : "N = 4"
and h1 : "probability = (\<lambda>n. fact N / fact (N - n) / (fact n * fact N))"
shows  "probability 2 = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A bag contains 4 distinguishable items. A probability function is defined as $P(n) = \frac{4!}{(4-n)!n!}$. What is the probability of selecting exactly 2 items out of 4? The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>x\<in>{(a, b, c, d) | a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> d}. 1 / card {(a, b, c, d) | a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> d})"
and h1 : "card {(a, b, c, d) | a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> d} = 9"
shows  "probability = 1 / 4"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Given any pair of the 4 CDs, there is exactly one arrangement with only these two CDs in the correct cases, because each of the remaining two CDs must be in the case of the other one.
 Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>x\<in>{(a, b, c, d) | a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> d}. 1 / card {(a, b, c, d) | a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> d})"
and h1 : "card {(a, b, c, d) | a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> d} = 9"
shows  "probability = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the probability of selecting a combination of 4 distinct elements (a, b, c, d) from a set of 9 elements, where no two elements are equal (a ≠ b, a ≠ c, a ≠ d, b ≠ c, b ≠ d, c ≠ d). The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_7.formal problem:

fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "exactly_two_in_wrong_cases_probability probability"
shows  "probability = 1/4"
a_7.formal solution:

 Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{4}

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "exactly_two_in_wrong_cases_probability probability"
shows  "probability = 1/4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the probability of exactly two cases being wrong, given that the probability is between 0 and 1 (inclusive). The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (1 / factorial 4) * (2 * factorial 2)"
shows  "P = 1 / 4"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Given any pair of the 4 CDs, there is exactly one arrangement with only these two CDs in the correct cases, because each of the remaining two CDs must be in the case of the other one.
 Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (1 / factorial 4) * (2 * factorial 2)"
shows  "P = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the value of $P$ if $P = \frac{1}{4!} \cdot (2 \cdot 2!)$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum> k : {0..4}. (4 choose k) * (-1)^k / fact (4 - k))"
shows  "probability = 1/4"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Without looking at the labels, Adrien placed four CDs in four cases. What is the probability that exactly two of the CDs are in the wrong cases? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Given any pair of the 4 CDs, there is exactly one arrangement with only these two CDs in the correct cases, because each of the remaining two CDs must be in the case of the other one.
 Therefore, there are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ arrangements of the CDs for which exactly two of the CDs are in the correct case. The probability that one of these 6 arrangements will be chosen from among the $4!=24$ equally likely arrangements is $\dfrac{6}{24}=\boxed{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum> k : {0..4}. (4 choose k) * (-1)^k / fact (4 - k))"
shows  "probability = 1/4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the probability given by the formula: $P = \sum_{k=0}^4 \frac{(-1)^k \binom{4}{k}}{4!}$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.
